title: david-mundell-aiming-to-develop-trade-links-ahead-of-brexit-with-reykjavik-visit
story: Mr Mundell will travel to Iceland on Friday aiming to further develop trade links ahead of the UKs departure from the EU.:David Mundell fails to sayUK will leave EU on March , only that he wants it toHe will visit biotech company Ossur, the HB Grandi Fish processing plant and the University of Iceland, as well as meeting with the Icelandic fishing minister."As the UK prepares to leave the EU, it is vital that we do all we can to promote trade with partners, both old and new, around the world," he said."Scotland and Iceland have strong cultural, academic and economic connections, and I look forward to building on these with my trip this week."I will be promoting Scottish business and skills - particularly in fishing and biotech - and I hope we will be able to further develop those relationships in the future.":David Mundell faces cross-party calls to resignTrade between the United Kingdom and Iceland was estimated to be worth around pound. billion in the year to September . The countries both have strong fishing and fish processing industries.Mr Mundell will also be the guest of honour at an LGBT ersity reception at the British Embassy in Reykjavik, celebrating the UK and Icelands shared commitment to LGBT rights.

title: craig ascends bennachie 100 times
story: A Kemnay man ascended Bennachie  times in just one year.Craig Thomson completed the achievement on Sunday, December , .His friend, Ross Henderson, joined Craig on the milestone expedition.Ross said: “I met Craig back in  and a few months after, he spoke about wanting to do Bennachie  times in a year.“The main motivation behind this was the memory of a friend of his, Malcolm, who died of Neuofibromatosis.“Malcolm succombed to the condition shortly after he and Craig had completed an ascent of Bennachie so it is entirely fitting that he should complete such a challenge.”“I quite often saw Craig’s car heading out towards Bennachie on many an occasion, sometimes when it was dark.“I did join him on a few expeditions out on the hill, one of them we timed well as we ed to the car park when it was dusky.“I hadn’t heard much from Craig until a few days before Christmas when he sent me a text askingI wanted to join him for the th ascent.“On the day a few of us met up at the back of Bennachie car park, there were  of us and three dogs so an excellent turnout.“He handed us all a program for the day which contained a written discription of his previous ascents and how he had built up to the full .“In  he managed  and in  he reached  and then stopped counting as it was getting late in the year.”The group set off and after an hour or so they had reached the summit of Oxen Craig, Bennachie’s highest peak.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! pupils Tami Fadeyiand Ruairidh Cummingunveiled a ceremonial plaquePupils in the school’s choir sang two songs at the ceremony while a video documenting the construction project played alongside them.The £m project was completed last year and pupils have been at the school since August.During the building’s construction more than  pupils were taken by bus daily to nearby Midmill School for  months, following a fire in the old building back in .Temporary accommodation on site was made for the nursery children.The new library space at Kinellar SchoolThe new school is built on the same site as its predecessor. As part of the build, the project team used the opportunity to improve facilities in the village by redeveloping a derelict tennis court and constructing an enclosed children’s play park as well as additional parking for use by the school and local community.The school’s social staircase is already becoming a well-used architectural feature alongside its many other bright and airy flexible learning spaces, including the glass fronted library and learning area upstairs.Its teaching wings benefit from cleverly designed acoustics, modern set up and technology offerings in all  classrooms, and are on two levels, with lightwells connecting them.Specially commissioned artwork is also an important feature of the new school.Local artists worked with pupils to design and create a number of pieces, including a large Oak tree in the dining area symbolizing growth with leaves painted by every child. title: inspectors praise north east nursery
story: Education inspectors have expressed confidence in the ongoing improvements being made at Rothienorman Pre-School Nursery.A recent visit led to the village hall facility being described as a “welcome and nurturing environment” and Inspectors said children were “happy, enthusiastic, and developing confidence”.Key strengths included a “dedicated team” which inspectors said have developed positive relationships and a “strong sense of community”.But the nursery has been asked to improve in certain areas, including increased use of national guidance to develop a “robust and rigorous approach to self-evaluation”. Inspectors said this will enable practitioners to identy what is working well and what needs to improve.They also want to see development of approaches to assessment and planning to help improve the quality of learning experiences and provide “greater depth and challenge” for all children.Improvements are also being sought in the development of practitioners’ knowledge and understanding of how to support children’s early language and mathematical thinking.Inspectors are confident that the setting has the capacity to continue to improve and will make no more visits in connection with this inspection.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The group at the summit of Oxen Craig - Craig Thomson is pictured th left"  Craig ascends Bennachie  times viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: kintore flats plans raise objections
story: Councillors will next week debate proposals for  new affordable flats in the heart of Kintore which have attracted a host of objections.Langstane Housing Association has tabled plans for four property blocks featuring  one-bed flats and six two-bed flats on vacant waste ground on Forest Road.But  objections have been raised on the grounds of insufficient parking and road safety, increased traffic and congestion on Forest Road and the scale of the development and the adverse impact on the amenity.In a report to Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee which meets on Tuesday, director of infrastructure services Stephen Archer says that “on balance” while the development may have an amenity impact on the neighbouring properties, it will fall within acceptable standards.He says: “The proposal for  affordable flats would make a positive contribution to affordable housing provision in Kintore.“It is accepted that any development on this site will alter the outlook from neighbouring dwellings, however, the use of the site for a flatted development is considered compatible with the infill nature of the site and settlement location.”Councillors will be told that the pre-application consultations and discussions during the determination of the application to reduce the potential impact on the neighbouring properties has resulted in the final layout and design.But in its objection, Kintore Community Council slams the proposal, particularly in terms of inadequate parking spaces.Chair Fiona Cooper states: “The proposed parking for the development of  spaces for  residents is insufficient and would result in overspill parking on the oppositie side of the road which would obviously have a major affect on existing residents.”In terms of the scale of the development, the community council recommends a maximum of two-storeys, with Mrs Cooper adding: “The proposed development by reason of size is out of character and would have an unacceptably adverse impact on the amenities of the properties immediately opposite the site and the surrounding area by reason of overlooking and having a visually overbearing impact.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk story: Nominations are being sought to fill  vacancies on Bennachie Community Council.Ideally the Community Council is looking for representation from the settlements of Chapel of Garioch, Culsalmond, Insch, Oyne, Premnay and Rayne.Completed forms must be ed by  pm on Monday, March .An election will only take place on Tuesday, March from . pm and . pm at Insch Institute,nominees exceed the vacancies.The community council’s meeting following the election is due to take place on Monday  March  in the Insch Institute.Nomination forms are now available to collect from the Garioch Area Office in Gordon House on Blackhall Road, Inverurie or email garioch@aberdeenshire.gov.uk.Forms are also available from the Community Council by emailing bennachiecc@outlook.Forms can also be found locally in N S Wilson, Chemist, Insch.For further information about the vacancies please email Alison Cumming Alison.cumming@aberdeenshire.gov.uk or call  .Further information on community councils can be found online here or visit wwwmunitycouncils.scot.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Last years top price animal, a champion heer, sold for #,"  Strong entry of calves for Spring Show viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: playgroup donates nativity cash to charity
story: A north east charity has received a welcome cash boost from an Inverurie playgroup.St Andrew’s Church Playgroup held a Nativity show just before Christmas and the event raised more than £.Through kind donations from parents, grandparents and other family members, as well as cash from raffle sales and refreshments, a total of £, was raised.The playgroup decided to donate the money to Spikin Autism and More , a parent peer support group for families or carers that have children with autism or other disabilities.The group provides a welcoming, relaxed environment for parents to not only share experiences, resources and information to help their children, but also to reduce their own feelings of ‘being alone’ and to provide one another with some much needed supportRepresentatives from the charity visited the playgroup on Friday, January  to accept the donation.Speaking to the Herald, Lisa Moir of SAAM said: “The money will go towards organising training sessions that will provide help on topics including dyslexia, speech and language.“We previously receviedfunding from the Garioch Partnership so we will add this money to that.“We want to help give more people the opportunity to have access to help with childcare issues.“The training sessions are open to everyone and we hope to have day and evening workshops.”Spikin Autism and More is based in Alford but started Peer Support Sessions at Homestart Garioch just over a year ago.Lisa created the group following the death of her husband.She added: “After he died I found it quite isolating finding support to raise our son who was three at the time and diagnosed with autism.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: to move or not to move that is the brexit question
story: Should people hold off putting those for sale signs up until the summer To move or not to move A study by the HomeOwners Alliance found that just  per centof people said their decision to stay where they are was based on concerns over Brexit, with more popular answers relating to lack of suitable homes and property prices.Russell Quirk, founded and CEO of hybrid estate agent Emoov said:ldquoThis research shows that Brexit isnrsquot the driving factor behind many UK home sellers looking to move or stay put and while we have seen the market slow due to the uncertain future of our partnership with the EU, the market is showing positive signs of recovery across the board.ldquoWhile this may strengthen once a Brexit deal is finalised there is no guarantee as to the outcome, and so those looking to sell should rest assured that now is as good a time as any to sell their home and later might not necessarily be better.Property commentator and buying agent Henry Pryor told the HomeOwners Alliance that he didnrsquot think that Brexit would have an impact straight away.ldquoJust like New Years Eve  when people wonderedplanes would fall out of the sky ortheir microwave would stop working because of the Millennium Bug I expect that March  will have a similar effect.ldquoWho seriously lsquoknowsrsquo what the impact of our actual orce from Europe will be ldquoThe three Drsquos will continue to provide a supply of sellers over the next year ndash death, debt and orce wonrsquot wait for Mrs May and Co to sort this out but there will be far fewer buyers who lsquomustrsquo purchase.ldquoAs a professional buyer, I am expecting to be especially busy as the more squeamish buyers ask for help making what in more normal times might be considered insulting offers. Brexiteers may claim that like other lsquoProject Fearrsquo predictions the anticipated damage to house prices has not been felt but I suspect they will be a bit more muted in a years time.If the Government negotiates a deal with the EU before March nothing will change until December , .The overriding answer seems to be that there is too much uncertainty at the moment soyou feel it is the right time to move, do it.Read more: Should I renew my EHIC card or will Brexit make it invalid data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.cumbernauld-news webimage ..! title: strong entry of calves for spring show
story: Some of the best commercial calves in the country will be forward at the Royal Northern Spring Show, held in conjunction with Aberdeen and Northern Marts.The annual event, which will be held at the Thainstone Centre on Wednesday, February , has attracted a strong entry of  calves from noted breeders.John and Craig Robertson from Newton of Logierait, Pitlochry, regularly dominate the show and sale, having scooped the supreme championship six times since . Last year, they sold the top price animal at £, for their champion heer and sold three others for £,, £, and £,.This year, the Robertsons have  calves entered including a full sister to last year’s top price heer.Huntly and Insch duo, Blair Duffton and Rebecca Stuart, will alsoto this year’s event with five calves, as will Ian Miller of Miller Farms, North Lurg, Midmar, who has four calves entered.Judging the commercial cattle entries, which will occur following the show and sales of bulls, will be well-known pedigree and commercial producer, Melanie Alford.John Angus, head of livestock at Thainstone, said: “The livestock sale element of the Royal Northern Spring Show is a fast-growing part of the event and we are delighted to be working once again with the Royal Northern Agricultural Society. The Spring Show is now recognised as the number one place for buyers from near and far to come and source quality calves with further showing potential.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"DIGG Councillor Martin Ford"  Councillors keen to prevent cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: This weeks Caithness Courier
story: Due to circumstances beyond our control, this weekrsquos edition of the Caithness Courier wonrsquot be in the shops until Thursday morning. We apologise for any inconvenience but this was due to a combination of problems with our contract printers and distribution partners.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Friday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: airports chairwoman is appointed
story: IT HAS been announced by Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity, Michael Matheson MSP, that Lorna Jack had been appointed as chairwoman of the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited , operators of several airports, including Kirkwall Airport.Ms Jack is a chartered accountant and a graduate of Aberdeen University. She joined the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited as a non-executive director in March  and chaired its Audit Committee for over three years, until she was invited to take on the interim chair role in October .Ms Jack remains the chief executive of the Law Society of Scotland and is an independent member of the Court of University of Aberdeen and a member of its Governance and Nominations Committee. She is also a trustee and treasurer of the McConnell International Foundation.The appointment is regulated by the Commissioner for Ethical Standards in Public Le in Scotland.• Highlands and Islands Airports Limitedis a public body wholly owned by Scottish Ministers. title: bus feedback events to return
story: Following the success of the event held in February , Bus Users Scotland willto Orkney this month to run another “Your Bus Matters” event to hear feedback on the bus services on the island. The events are open to everyone and will be held in Kirkwall and Stromness.The events give everyone the opportunity to provide feedback on what is working and what doesn’t about the local bus service. Representatives from Stagecoach will also be present to hear feedback on the services provided on the island.Greig Mackay, deputy director for Bus Users Scotland said: “We are looking forward to ing to Orkney to hear the views of the bus passengers. We were really pleased with the engagement at our event last year and look forward to hearing from more of the locals on the bus services on the island.”The two meetings will take place, later this month. Firstly, at Kirkwall Travel Centre on Monday, February , pm-pm, and then in Stromness on Tuesday, February , am-.pm.David Liston, managing director for Stagecoach North Scotland added: “We always welcome feedback on the services we provide and there is no better way to gather this than to host an event in partnership with Bus Users Scotland.#The feedback we received last year really helped us to develop improvements across the island demonstrated by the enhancements we made to services throughout the summer in . We are keen to hear what worked and what didn’t last year to help us shape our plans for .”If you can’t make the events you can still provide feedback to yourbusmatters@bususers.org.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: featured property of the week 5
story: Offers over £,ADVERTORIAL: Westermill is an eye-catching period property located close to the centre of Kirkwall. The property is detached and comprises a large entrance hallway,  spacious bedrooms, one with ensuite, living room, dining room, kitchen, shower room, utility room and downstairs toilet. The property benefits from a large enclosed mature garden to the rear of the property and there are also a driveway and shed to the side of the house.The property has oil-fired central heating, together with a fireplace in the dining room and a Morso stove in the sitting room. There are also fireplaces in two of the bedrooms. Many of the original features have been retained in the property. Viewing is highly recommended to appreciate the true character of Westermill.The property is ideally located on a quiet road close to both the Papdale Primary and Kirkwall Grammar School and it is only a few minutes walk down to the centre of town. To the front of the property is the picturesque Willowburn, as well as additional parking.The living room has a hardwood floor, picture rail and cornice, as does the dining room. There is an archway leading from the dining room to the modern fitted kitchen with  ring hob, double oven, cooker hood, fridge and dishwasher.The ground floor also houses the utility room with plumbing for a washing machine and space for tumble dryer and fridge  freezer. There is a small toilet off the utility room. One of the bedrooms is situated on the ground floor, but could be used as a living room or office space.In the centre of the property is a beautul staircase leading up to a large stained glass feature window and then on to the landing. Off the landing there are a further three double bedrooms, one of which has an en-suite shower room. The main shower room is also located on the first floor of the property.There is a large loft space which is partially floored and could potentially be converted into a further one or two rooms, with ample space on the landing for a staircase.There is a walled garden to the front of the property, bordered with bushes and shrubs. The large rear garden has mature trees and bushes, making the garden area extremely sheltered and private. There is also a patio area and garden shed.Viewing is highly recommended to fully appreciate all that this property has to offer.The Home Report is available by email on request.For further information and to arrange a viewing, please contact Kerry Croy Tel:  . title: german company revealed as third bidder for northern isles ferry tender
story: INTERNATIONAL ferry company FRS Group have been revealed as the third bidder for the Northern Isles ferry service.The company, headquartered in Flensburg, Germany, confirmed the news this week.#FRS follows the tender process. But please understand that we will not disclose any further information on this tender at this time.#It was last month that the Scottish Government stated that an invitation to tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services had been issued to three bidders.The names of the companies involved were not released by the government, however Serco NorthLink and Calmac did confirm their involvement.When asked last month, previous bidder Streamline confirmed that it was not one of the bidders on this occasion, leading to speculation over the final company involved.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July, said the Scottish Government. The contract is estimated to be worth £m, and will run for eight years.FRS Group runs ferry services throughout many areas of the world, including Europe, North Africa, the Middle East and North America.The organisation is also involved in maritime consultancy and offshore logistics.According to the company, FRS has grown from a regional passenger ferry operator into an internationally active group with  vessels and more than , employees from more than a dozen countries all over the world.FRS annually carries . million passengers and . million vehicles on its numerous national and international shipping lines.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney youth conference takes place
story: Orkney#s biennial Youth Conference, held at the Kirkwall Town Hall yestrday, organised by the OIC#s Community Learning and Development Service, brought together  young people from across Orkney to take part in workshops and hear from keynote speakers on a range of issues.The conference was opened by council Convener Harvey Johnston, who said he was truly delighted and privileged to be at the conference, amongst Orkney#s young people.He continued: #Our young folk are Orkney#s greatest asset and I#m expecting great things from you all. Not just today at this conference, but in your lives to come.#Taking to the stage next was keynote speaker John Loughton. John is a high profile and award winning global youth leader, social entrepreneur, campaigner and leadership speaker. He is founder and CEO of global leadership company DareLead. In  he was elected the youngest ever Chair of the Scottish Youth Parliament.On the back of yesterday#s Orkney Youth Conference, local folk in Orkney who work with children and young people, are gathering today for the third Growing Up in Orkney conference.Today’s conference gives them the opportunity to share and learn from each other as well as find out what’s working well in our communities. title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. It#s anticipated this work will start on February  and could take four weeks to complete.The current one-way system means drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street but vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street.A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. This initial phase of the project is due for completion early May after which works will be suspended for the main summer season.Work at the entrance to Victoria Street is set to begin in the autumn, with a suspension planned, in December for Christmas shopping season.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. title: Black Isle cafes Brexit talk ban raises cash for worthy cause
story: The tongue-in-cheek bid to banish the Brexit blues at Rosemarkie Beach Cafeacute over the festive season saw customers warned theyrsquod face a pound finethey so much as mentioned a word seldom out of the headlines lately.Philip Eley, the long-standing cafeacute manager, explained. ldquoItrsquos just grim. People are so depressed. Folk come to the beach to get away from all those headlines about what the idiots in Westminster are up to, but it only takes one person to mention the B-word to ruin everyone rsquos bacon roll.Customers warmed to the idea and willingly dropped contributions in the bucket during visits to the Black Isle beauty spot.Mr Eleyrsquos partner, Verity Walker, made good on a promise to donate takings from the offbeat bucket collection to the Maggiersquos Highlands cancer care centre at Raigmore Hospital. It was gratefully accepted by fundraising manager David Walker, who is no relation. Ms Walker said: ldquoWe finally got the donations bucket and collecting can to the Maggiersquos Centre at Raigmore ndash they were quite heavy as we kept them on the counter a bit longer and you just kept on giving!ldquoMaggiersquos has helped a number of cafeacute customers and staff. They exist to support those who are affected by cancer, but that includes the families of those diagnosed. If you have never been in, please go and visit, itrsquos a lovely calm space amid the hustle and bustle of Raigmore.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle festival issues tongue in cheek invite to ex Oasis star
story: The announcement last week that Noel Gallagher and his High Flying Birds will take to the stage in Inverness on June  was greeted with delight by fans of the multimillion-selling star who shot to fame as the creative force behind Oasis.Less thrilled about the timing of the Bught Park gig, organised by Live in the City and boasting support from Razorlight and Neon Waltz, were the organisers of the Black Isle-based Woodzstock, scheduled to take place on the same date in an outdoor adventure park near Tore, just a few miles from Gallaghers headline-grabbing gig.Woodzstock organisers Charlotte and Dave Elliott admit they were rocked ndash and not in a good way ndash when they learned of the clash. Within hours they rallied with a defiant show must go on plan ndash to invite Gallagher to perform at their intimate venue ahead of his own show in the Highland capital.Charlotte said: "Were excited that big names like Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds are coming to the Highlands andwe werent holding our festival on the same day we would have loved to see them play. We didnt want to miss him so were inviting Noel to come along and play a few tunes at Woodzstock before his gig in Inverness."She added: "We know it a long shot! Were asking the public to help us by posting online sharing the hashtag #GetNoeltoWoodz"Now entering its third year, Woodzstock has grown year on year with more bands, festival-goers and local businesses, including food producers, artists and performers, sound engineers and local charities, benefiting.Charlotte said: "This year promises to the best Woodzstock yet, we have some fantastic bands already booked, amazing locally sourced food and drink and activities running for the kids. An appearance from Noel would be amazing. We hope our invitation reaches him and he knows our stage will be ready for him".No one from Live in the City was available for comment on the fixture clash. Mr Gallagher could not be reached for comment.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Check your cold weather payment eligibility says Ross MP as temperature plummets
story: Local MP Ian Blackford sayspeople in the Ross, Skye and Lochaber constituency he serves should check eligibility with their nearest Job Centre Plus.This follows an alert of a triggering of the payment for postcode areas IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, between the period    to   .Cold weather payments are made from the Social Fund to certain recipients of Income Support, income-based Jobseekerrsquos Allowance, income-related Employment and Support Allowance, Universal Credit or Pension Credit during periods of very cold weather.To ldquotrigger the payments, the average temperature at a specied weather station must be recorded as, or forecast to be, degC or below for seven consecutive days.The scheme runs from November  to March  each year.The payment is a fixed amount for each week of cold weather. For many years this was set at pound. a week but the LabourGovernment increased the rate to pound a week as a temporary measure for winters - and -. In , the Coalition Government made the pound rate permanent.Payments should be made automatically to those entitled to them there should be no need to make a claim.However concerns have previously been raised that payments can be missed and Mr Blackford believes it is important that people, who believe that they may be eligible follow this through, particularly as the cold weather bites.He said: ldquoWe have been experiencing quite a prolonged period of cold and wet weather in the Highlands and Islands. It is hugely important that anyone eligible for a cold weather payment receives it. It can really make a dference to a vulnerable person or family who is experiencing high heating costs.ldquoThese payments should be made to eligible iniduals automatically, however, in my experience that is not always the case. I would urge anyone who believes that they may be due a payment to contact their nearest Job Centre Plus and get what they are owed.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross Post Offices affected by shops move
story: SHOP closures in two Easter Ross towns could leave the Post Office seeking new premises from which to operate.The changes affect Invergordon and Tain.A Post Office spokesperson said: ldquoWe are aware that our partner CJ Lang who runs Invergordon Post Office, has given us notice and the store will be closing later this year.ldquoThe branch was run independently and while we always work hard to maintain Post Office services, from time to time, branches do temporarily close. When this happens, we always look to restore services as quickly as possible, as we know how important Post Offices are to communities.ldquoWe would like to reassure customers that we are committed to maintaining vital Post Office services for the local community.The spokesman also confirmed that in Tain its partner McCollrsquos Retail Group, which runs the Post Office, has also given notice ldquoand the store will be closing in the spring.He said that branch is also run independently and efforts will be made to restore services as quickly as possible.He said: ldquoWe have had interest from some local retailers who are interested in running this branch but it is very early stages so we are unable to comment further at the moment. ldquoWe would like to reassure customers that we are committed to maintaining vital Post Office services for the local community ndash including banking services like cash withdrawals from high street bank account, bill payments, and of course a wide range of postal services.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland air traffic controllers to be balloted on strike action
story: A BALLOT that could lead to strike action resulting in disruption to flights across the Highlands is due to open next week.The Prospect union confirmed it is going ahead with the ballot of air traffic control members at Highlands and islands airports in a dispute over pay with their employers, Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd .The ballot will run from February  to March  andmembers back industrial action, a series of one-day strikes could start on April  and run throughout the summer.As well as affecting Inverness Airport operations could also be disruptedat Benbecula, Dundee, Kirkwall, Stornoway, Sumburgh and Wick John OGroats.Members are also being askedthey wish to take action short of an all-out strike that could include working to rosters an overtime ban and refusing extensions to airport opening hours for non-medical flights.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: ldquoMembers do not wish to take this action but have been forced into this position by the refusal of ministers to engage with the issue of air traffic controllersrsquo pay.Hial is owned by the Scottish Government which last week said all staff had been given a pay rise which was a ldquosignicant improvement on previous years.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: New homes planned for Dingwall
story: DINGWALL moved a step closer to getting  new homes after the Ross and Cromarty area committee agreed an infrastructure investment ldquounlocking the possibility of the development.But councillors were at odds over the plans with some considering them a sop in lieu of the  homes earmarked for the town since  while others said it was a ldquopositive move in a high pressure area for housing demand.The original plan was based on the delivery of the Kinnairdie Link Roadproject ndash expected to unleash millions in inward investment. It was due to start its final phase of construction this year but it was axed from the councilrsquos capital programme in last yearrsquos budget.Then in March, funding for transport improvements in Dingwall was found to enable some housing development to take place prior to the commencement of the KLR.A transport study and modelling work considered the impact of ious levels of development in the town and improvements will include work at the Bridgend Avenue Junction and Docharty Road Junction as well as traffic signal works at Mart Road Junction. Proposals for walking and cycling improvements and traffic management measures will also be brought forward to enhance active travel facilities in the town.Dingwall and Seaforth councillor Graham Mackenzie said: ldquoIt would be tempting to see it as a good news story for Dingwall. That is not the case. Had we been given what we were promised in an earlier iteration of the capital plan we could be releasing up to  houses for development instead of around ."Instead the KLR was taken out of the capital plan even though the first phase of the project had already started. If Dingwall is to grow and provide the range of housing which is required, the KLR must be moved up the list of priorities. This project needs to be reinstated.Fellow ward councillor Angela Maclean insisted the deal was good news. She said: ldquoWe as councillors have a leadership role and it is up to us to be helping our communities to move forward and this report has examples of when officers have looked for solutions to get round some of the fact that we donrsquot have all the money we would like."Whether it is through the infrastructure road plans or capital fund we are going to try and move forward with these houses in Dingwall, because Dingwall is a pressurised area ndash this is a positive move because we donrsquot have enough houses in Dingwall.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Old office goes back on market in Dingwall
story: The former assessorrsquos office in Ferry Road, which adjoins the old Sherf Court, dates back to .A category B listed commercial property it was on the market a year ago and it was thought a buyer had been found. But the sale fell through and the property is again up for sale with offers over pound, invited.Originally built as a police station, the property has a colourful history with its location next to the courthouse.The sherf court was closed by the Scottish Court Service in January  as part of a cost-cutting and restructuring scheme.The following year the property was sold and converted into a private dwelling. The former police station been used for many years by Highland Council as offices for the assessor.The assessor is responsible for assigning a value to properties for tax purposes.Because it was a commercial property it is not necessary to provide a survey of the building to potential buyers.It is in a mix of modern and traditional residential properties close to the town centre on Ferry Road.Of stone and slate construction it comprises three rooms on the ground floor and four rooms on the first floor.A council spokesman said the property requires extensive work, but it has its own entrance and parking to the front of the property.The closing date set for offers is March , .Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. story: Strathpeffer Community Centre is hosting the quiz night on Friday, February  in support of the Puffin Hydrotherapy Pool in Dingwall, which has launched a pound, appeal to repair defective equipment.The pool has provided thousands of sessions for people with a range of conditions which benefit from hydrotherapy.Tickets for the .pm event are priced at pound for a table of six and include live music from the Thistle Tomes plus home baking and soft drinks. title: Ross nurses lead the way
story: Chrissie Laneand Lucy Heycockentered the gruelling Strathpeffer -hour mountain bike challenge with the aim of encouraging some of their patients and colleagues to embrace new challenges and experiences.The annual event near Strathpeffer sees riders tackle freezing temperatures,  hours of darkness and mile upon mile of frozen forest tracks.The dynamic duo were delighted with a podium finish. Macmillan cancer consultant nurse Chrissie, from Culbokie, said: ldquoWe work every day with amazing people living with cancer and are trying to support them to be active outdoors which has huge proven benefits to their health and recovery.ldquoMaking small or big changes to the amount of moving your body does throughout the day have immense benefits for people living with cancer.Theyrsquore promoting everything from short walks and cycle rides to hillwalking.Chrissie added: ldquoThe reason why we took part in the event was to try to be role models for older woman to just give experiences a try. All it needs is a gritty frame of mind and a sense of humour and fun when situations are not so pleasant.Chrissie and advanced nurse colleague Lucy, from Muir of Ord, were delighted with a podium finish, coming in an extremely credible third in the competitionrsquos female pairs category.Both Chrissie and Lucy hope that their success shows that you can take up and enjoy exercise, even doing an event like the challenging Strathpuffer, at any age.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Tain hub and Picture House project progress to come under spotlight
story: Tain and District Development Trusthas already been successful in raising well over pound, towards its projects and secured three employed positions for the local area.On Thursday, February the group is staging a community consultation in the towns Duthac Centre at pm.TDDTs Sarah Mackenzie said: "Weve worked hard to gain a closer relationship with local businesses and groups within Tain and district in order to increase our social and economic impact to the local area making us more attractive to potential funders and investors."To date we have bid and successfully received funding for ourselves and partner projects from FirstPort, Highlands and Islands Enterprise, SSE Beatrice Wind Farm, Beinn Tharsuinn Wind farm Trust and Highland Council."With these funds we are now in a position to employ a community fund manager, business development manager and an administrator to help take our projects to the next level and increase our community-wide benefit. We hope to have these positions filled by early spring."The funds will also allowTDDT to fit out its new community enterprise hub on Stafford Street inTain.Said Ms Mackenzie: "The hub will be the cornerstone to all of our projects as well as providing a space that caters to the wider community offering conferencing facilities, meeting rooms, hot desking andpop-up phops. We hope to be open for business in March this year."Highlands and Islands Enterpriseis providing funding support towards the cost of developing the hub and recruiting a manager.Stewart Wardlaw, HIE Development Manager, Inner Moray Firth area, said: "The Hub will provide valuable business services locally, for commercial and social enterprises."It will also help facilitate the use of business premises within the local community and in a town centre location. This will help make the Tain district a more attractive option for businesses and drive growth locally."We are very pleased to be able to provide support and look forward to seeing the project develop.Through the SSE Beatrice Wind Farm Fund, TDDThas received funds to cover the costs for a full business plan and feasibility study towards the Picture House project.Along with Tain Heritage Trust and Tain and Easter Ross Civic Trust,TDDT hasalready managed to successfully clear the outside of the premises andtidy up inside,allowing the community a rare glimpse of a building through photographs thatmany hold close to their hearts.The Beatrice Partnership Fund said it wasdelighted to support the community withits aspirations to restorethe iconic local building.Tain Heritage Trusts Chairman David Robertson welcomed the support theyve had in recent months from Tain  Easter Ross Civic Trust and from Tain  District Development Trust to help kick-start the Picture House redevelopment.He said: "This help has now secured us funding for a feasibilitystudy from SSE.We welcome the involvement of SSE in what really would be a transformational project for the town."Lets hope this is the start of a fruitful partnership with them to secure the phased restoration of our Royal Burghs much-loved hall. story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Controversial plans to take trams to Newhaven will carry a #m price tag - with the final business case costs soaring by an extra  per cent.City councillors will get their first chance to examine the confidential final business case todayat a “special data room” at City Chambers - before the full council decides whether or not to approve the extension on  March.If the extension is approved by councillors, the works should be completed by  and operational in the first quarter of .
